tier_0_classification.classification_reasoning: The question requires calculating eigenvalues from given phugoid motion characteristics. It involves understanding damping ratio and natural frequency, and then applying the relationship to find the eigenvalues. It requires multiple steps and integrates concepts from flight dynamics.

answer_validation.reasoning:
Phugoid motion is modeled as a lightly damped second-order mode with complex eigenvalues \(\lambda = \sigma \pm i\omega_d\). From the data:

1) 10 cycles in 50 s \Rightarrow period \(T = 5\,	ext{s}\). The damped frequency is \(\omega_d =  rac{2\pi}{T} =  rac{2\pi}{5} \approx 1.257\,	ext{rad/s}\).

2) Amplitude reduces to half in 25 s. For a mode with real part \(\sigma < 0\), amplitude decays as \(e^{\sigma t}\). The half-life condition is \(e^{\sigma T_{1/2}} = 	frac{1}{2}\). Thus \(\sigma T_{1/2} = \ln(1/2) = -\ln 2\), so \(\sigma = - rac{\ln 2}{T_{1/2}} = - rac{0.693}{25} \approx -0.0277\,	ext{s}^{-1}\).

Therefore eigenvalues are approximately \(\lambda = -0.028 \pm 1.26 i\). Option C matches this. Option D has the correct imaginary part but positive real part (unstable), contradicting the given decaying amplitude. Options A and B have much smaller imaginary parts (frequencies) inconsistent with 10 cycles in 50 s.

step_by_step: Identify that the phugoid mode is a lightly damped oscillatory mode, so its eigenvalues are complex conjugates: \(\lambda = \sigma \pm i\omega_d\), where \(\sigma\) is the decay rate and \(\omega_d\) is the damped angular frequency.
Use the given number of cycles and time to find the period: 10 cycles in 50 s implies period \(T = 50/10 = 5\,\text{s}\). Compute the damped frequency as \(\omega_d = 2\pi/T\).
Compute \(\omega_d = 2\pi/5 \approx 1.257\,\text{rad/s}\), which will be the imaginary part of the eigenvalues.
Use the amplitude decay information: amplitude halves in 25 s. For a mode with real part \(\sigma\), amplitude \(A(t) = A_0 e^{\sigma t}\). Set \(A(25) = A_0/2\) and solve for \(\sigma\).
From \(A_0 e^{\sigma\cdot 25} = A_0/2\), obtain \(e^{25\sigma} = 1/2\). Taking natural log gives \(25\sigma = \ln(1/2) = -\ln 2\), so \(\sigma = -\ln 2 / 25 \approx -0.0277\,\text{s}^{-1}\).

Combine the real and imaginary parts to write the eigenvalues: \(\lambda = -0.0277 \pm 1.257 i\). Round to two or three significant figures to match options: \(-0.028 \pm 1.26 i\), which corresponds to option C.

topic.name: Aircraft dynamic stability and modes (longitudinal phugoid mode)
topic.syllabus_ref: Flight Mechanics -> Static and dynamic stability -> Longitudinal modes (short period, phugoid)

concepts.name: Exponential decay and time to half amplitude

essential: Understanding of aircraft longitudinal dynamic modes (short period and phugoid)
Basics of second-order linear systems and complex conjugate roots
Relationship between period and angular frequency (T and 2\pi/\omega)
Exponential decay law for dynamic systems (A(t) = A_0 e^{\sigma t})
helpful: Interpretation of damping ratio and natural frequency in flight dynamics
Physical understanding of phugoid as slow exchange of kinetic and potential energy

Main Concept: requires: Basics of linear ODE solutions with complex eigenvalues
requires: Knowledge of oscillation period and angular frequency relationship
enables: Ability to extract eigenvalues from flight test time histories
enables: Advanced analysis of flying qualities and handling criteria for phugoid mode

difficulty_factors: Requires recognizing that 10 cycles in 50 s gives the period directly
Needs comfort with exponential decay and natural logarithm to compute decay rate
Students may confuse damped frequency with undamped natural frequency, though only \(\omega_d\) is needed here

textbook_references.author: Robert C. Nelson
textbook_references.chapter_title: Longitudinal Static Stability and Dynamic Response

video_references.book_reference: Nelson - Flight Stability and Automatic Control
video_references.topic_covered: Identification of short period and phugoid modes, calculation of natural frequency and damping ratio from complex roots

video_references.book_reference: Nelson - Flight Stability and Automatic Control
video_references.topic_covered: Half-life (time to half amplitude) of longitudinal modes and relation to real part of eigenvalues

step_by_step_solution.solution_path: Interpret motion data \rightarrow Compute period and damped frequency \rightarrow Use amplitude decay to find real part \rightarrow Form complex eigenvalues \rightarrow Match with options
key_insights: Time history of oscillation directly gives period and thus damped frequency
Time to half amplitude is directly related to the real part of the eigenvalue via a simple logarithmic relation
Only the damped frequency \(\omega_d\) is needed, not the undamped natural frequency \(\omega_n\), for matching the given options

formulas_principles.name: Relation between period and damped angular frequency
formulas_principles.conditions: Applies to sinusoidal oscillations with damped angular frequency \omega_d
formulas_principles.relevance: Used to compute \omega_d from the observed period of phugoid oscillation

formulas_principles.name: Exponential decay of amplitude
formulas_principles.conditions: Applies to linear modes where the real part of eigenvalue is \sigma
formulas_principles.relevance: Relates time to half amplitude with the real part of the eigenvalue

formulas_principles.name: Decay rate from amplitude ratio
formulas_principles.conditions: Derived from A(t) = A_0 e^{\sigma t}
formulas_principles.relevance: Used to compute \sigma from the given half-life

formulas_principles.name: Complex eigenvalues of oscillatory mode
formulas_principles.relevance: Gives the final eigenvalues once \sigma and \omega_d are known

industry_examples: Flight test engineers excite the phugoid mode with small pitch or thrust inputs and record altitude and speed oscillations to estimate eigenvalues and verify compliance with handling qualities standards.
Autopilot designers use accurate phugoid eigenvalues to tune longitudinal control laws so that long-period oscillations are adequately damped and comfortable for passengers.
specific_systems: Transport aircraft such as the Airbus A320 or Boeing 737, where phugoid characteristics affect cruise and descent handling.
Gliders and sailplanes, where lightly damped phugoid oscillations are common and pilots must be trained to recognize and control them.
real_world_applications.practical_relevance: Correct estimation of phugoid eigenvalues is essential for assessing flying qualities, ensuring that long-period oscillations are either sufficiently damped or slow enough for pilots and automatic control systems to manage safely.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using frequency f = 10/50 = 0.2 Hz directly as the imaginary part of eigenvalues instead of converting to angular frequency \(\omega_d = 2\pi f\).
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They confuse linear frequency (cycles per second) with angular frequency (radians per second) and forget the 2\pi factor.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Always write the relation explicitly: \(\omega = 2\pi f\). Check units: Hz vs rad/s.
common_mistakes.consequence: Imaginary part becomes too small by a factor of about 6.28, leading to choosing options like A or B instead of C.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using base-10 logarithm instead of natural logarithm when computing \(\sigma\) from the half-life.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Calculator default log is base-10, and they forget that the exponential model uses natural exponentials.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Remember that \(e^{\sigma t}\) implies using ln (natural log). On calculators, use the ln key, not log.
common_mistakes.consequence: Gives an incorrect decay rate and hence wrong real part of eigenvalues.

common_mistakes.mistake: Choosing the option with positive real part (unstable) because the magnitude matches, ignoring the sign.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They focus on numerical magnitude and overlook the physical meaning of sign for stability.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Link sign to physics: decaying amplitude means \(\sigma < 0\). Growing amplitude would require \(\sigma > 0\).
common_mistakes.consequence: Leads to selecting option D instead of C, implying an unstable phugoid contradicting the given decay.

common_mistakes.mistake: Misinterpreting 'amplitude reduces to half in 25 s' as 25 s being the period or using 50 s instead of 25 s in the decay calculation.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They rush through the wording and mix up time to half amplitude with total observation time.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Underline key phrases: '10 cycles in 50 s' (for period) and 'half in 25 s' (for decay). Use them in separate steps.
common_mistakes.consequence: Incorrect real part of eigenvalues and wrong option.

mnemonics_memory_aids.mnemonic: F to W: Frequency to omega, multiply by 2\pi
mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Converting linear frequency f (Hz) to angular frequency \(\omega\) (rad/s)
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: Whenever you see cycles per second or period in dynamic stability problems

mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Relating time to half amplitude with decay rate using natural log
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: When computing decay rate from time to half amplitude in stability problems

flashcards.front: An oscillation has period T. What is its damped angular frequency \(\omega_d\)?
flashcards.back: For a sinusoidal oscillation, \(\omega_d = 2\pi/T\). If frequency is given in Hz (f), then \(\omega_d = 2\pi f\).

flashcards.front: Amplitude halves in time \(T_{1/2}\). What is the decay rate \(\sigma\) in \(A(t) = A_0 e^{\sigma t}\)?
For a stable phugoid mode with decaying oscillations, what is the sign of the real part of eigenvalues?
flashcards.back: Negative. Decaying amplitude implies \(\sigma < 0\) so eigenvalues lie in the left half of the complex plane.

flashcards.front: An aircraft shows 5 phugoid cycles in 40 s. Estimate \(\omega_d\).
Why must you use ln (not log10) when finding \(\sigma\) from \(A(t) = A_0 e^{\sigma t}\)?
flashcards.back: Because the exponential is base e. Taking natural log on both sides matches the base, giving \(\ln(A/A_0) = \sigma t\). Using log10 would require an extra conversion factor.

real_world_context.application: Flight test analysis of longitudinal stability
real_world_context.industry_example: During certification, test pilots perform small pitch or thrust disturbances and record altitude and speed. Engineers fit exponentials and sinusoids to extract phugoid eigenvalues and compare with handling quality criteria (e.g., minimum damping ratio or maximum time to double).
real_world_context.why_it_matters: If phugoid is too lightly damped or unstable, pilots may experience uncomfortable long-period oscillations, and autopilots may struggle to maintain smooth flight, affecting safety and passenger comfort.

exam_strategy.triage_tip: Recognize it as a standard dynamic-stability calculation: quickly compute period from cycles, convert to \(\omega_d\), then use the half-life formula for \(\sigma\). Minimal algebra, mostly plugging numbers.
exam_strategy.guessing_heuristic: If stuck, note that 10 cycles in 50 s implies \(\omega_d\) around 1.25 rad/s, so eliminate options with tiny imaginary parts (A, B). Decay implies negative real part, so choose C over D.
exam_strategy.time_management: Allocate about 2 minutes: 1 minute for frequency and decay calculations, 1 minute to check signs and match options.

search_keywords: time to half amplitude real part of eigenvalue
damped frequency period relation 2pi over T
A.K. Ghosh lecture phugoid half life

alternative_methods.name: Use logarithmic decrement over multiple cycles
alternative_methods.description: Instead of using the given half-life directly, one could compute the logarithmic decrement \(\delta\) from amplitude ratios over several cycles and then relate \(\delta\) to damping ratio and eigenvalues. However, this requires more data than provided here.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: More accurate when multiple amplitude measurements are available. Cons: Overkill for this problem, and not needed when half-life is directly given.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: When you have experimental time histories with several peaks and want to estimate damping ratio robustly.

connections_to_other_subjects.Control Systems: The relation between eigenvalues, damping ratio, and time response is identical to second-order control system analysis (step response, overshoot, settling time).
connections_to_other_subjects.Vibrations: Mechanical vibrations of mass-spring-damper systems use the same formulas for damped frequency and exponential decay of amplitude.
connections_to_other_subjects.Mathematics: Complex analysis and solutions of linear differential equations with constant coefficients underlie the eigenvalue-based description of modes.

deeper_dive_topics: Derivation of phugoid approximate characteristic equation using longitudinal stability derivatives
Handling qualities criteria for phugoid mode (damping ratio, time to double) from standards like MIL-F-8785
Effect of lift-to-drag ratio and flight speed on phugoid frequency and damping
Use of stability augmentation systems to improve phugoid damping in transport aircraft

syllabus_mapping.gate_section: Flight Mechanics: Static and dynamic stability
syllabus_mapping.gate_subsection: Longitudinal modes (short period, phugoid) and their characteristics
syllabus_mapping.feedback_for_syllabus_design: Excellent alignment: tests core ability to connect time-domain phugoid behavior with eigenvalues, a fundamental skill in dynamic stability analysis.

rag_quality.notes: RAG provided detailed context on phugoid mode characteristics, half-life, and relation between eigenvalues and time response (especially chunks 1, 2, 3, and 6). Although the exact numerical example differs, the formulas for time to half amplitude and interpretation of eigenvalues directly support solving this question.

future_questions_potential: Given phugoid eigenvalues, compute time to double amplitude and assess if it meets a specified handling quality requirement.
From measured altitude and speed time histories of a phugoid oscillation, estimate damping ratio and natural frequency, then compare with approximate analytical expressions.
Ask students to distinguish short period and phugoid modes from a set of eigenvalues and justify based on frequency and damping.
Include effect of changing flight speed or altitude on phugoid frequency and damping, requiring qualitative reasoning plus simple scaling relations.

response_json.subject: Aerospace Engineering
response_json.question_text: An aircraft in level flight encounters a vertical gust, which excites the phugoid mode. The phugoid motion completes 10 cycles in 50 s and its amplitude reduces to half of its maximum value in 25 s. The eigenvalues of the phugoid mode are
